Bachelor & Stanislav Rubin

1.Stanislav Rubin: Dear colleague! By some happy coincidence I managed to get my hands on a certain... vessel, that I believe I can recover the pathogen from. Which means we are now all set to research the vaccine! But, odd as it may sound, I'd rather avoid tapping into that... source I mentioned, unless I absolutely have to. I'd rather examine the samples that can be procured from the dead tissue.

1.Stanislav Rubin: Dear colleague! By some happy coincidence I managed to get my hands on a certain... vessel, that I believe I can recover the pathogen from. Which means we are now all set to research the vaccine! But, odd as it may sound, I'd rather avoid tapping into that... source I mentioned, unless I absolutely have to. I'd rather examine the samples that can be procured from the dead tissue.

2.Bachelor: Wait a moment... How can we possibly produce a vaccine with what scarce equipment we have?

2.Bachelor: Wait a moment... How can we possibly produce a vaccine with what scarce equipment we have?

3.Stanislav Rubin: It won't be a vaccine per se, but rather a solution that might temporarily bolster the immune system. True, I don't have much in the way of equipment, but I have plenty of reagents, herbal tinctures... twyrine infusions, by and large. The least we can expect is to keep ourselves reasonably safe until a better equipped team arrives.

3.Stanislav Rubin: It won't be a vaccine per se, but rather a solution that might temporarily bolster the immune system. True, I don't have much in the way of equipment, but I have plenty of reagents, herbal tinctures... twyrine infusions, by and large. The least we can expect is to keep ourselves reasonably safe until a better equipped team arrives.

4.Bachelor: Where are we going to get the dead tissue from?

4.Bachelor: Where are we going to get the dead tissue from?

5.Stanislav Rubin: I was going to ask you to bring a sample or two from one of the infected quarters. Be doubly careful though, and make sure to get the dissection fully cleared with one of the rulers, else the risk would be twice as high as needs be. I'd go myself, but there are reasons that make it impossible for me to leave Simon's body unattended.

5.Stanislav Rubin: I was going to ask you to bring a sample or two from one of the infected quarters. Be doubly careful though, and make sure to get the dissection fully cleared with one of the rulers, else the risk would be twice as high as needs be. I'd go myself, but there are reasons that make it impossible for me to leave Simon's body unattended.

6.Bachelor: That's some request... What is this additional danger you speak of?

6.Bachelor: That's some request... What is this additional danger you speak of?

7.Stanislav Rubin: Dissection of dead bodies is something that the locals strongly disapprove of. For Steppe people, the human body represents the world. Only a member of a special taglur-Burakh, to name one-is allowed to 'open it up'. This is a caste-based privilege, you see.

7.Stanislav Rubin: Dissection of dead bodies is something that the locals strongly disapprove of. For Steppe people, the human body represents the world. Only a member of a special taglur-Burakh, to name one-is allowed to 'open it up'. This is a caste-based privilege, you see.

8.Bachelor: Does everyone in the town share this same prejudice?

8.Bachelor: Does everyone in the town share this same prejudice?

9.Stanislav Rubin: No, of course not. But even those who are oblivious of the sacred meaning of the Kin's rituals would still oppose unsanctioned dissection, because it's traditionally inappropriate. A cultural taboo, if you will. An autopsy performed by anyone other than a true born menkhu is seen as blasphemy of the worst kind. Even incest is not as repulsive to them.

9.Stanislav Rubin: No, of course not. But even those who are oblivious of the sacred meaning of the Kin's rituals would still oppose unsanctioned dissection, because it's traditionally inappropriate. A cultural taboo, if you will. An autopsy performed by anyone other than a true born menkhu is seen as blasphemy of the worst kind. Even incest is not as repulsive to them.

10.Bachelor: Which doesn't stop them from being comfortable with all manner of slaughter.

10.Bachelor: Which doesn't stop them from being comfortable with all manner of slaughter.

11.Stanislav Rubin: These people are outlaws, and not a single one of them is a Steppe man.

11.Stanislav Rubin: These people are outlaws, and not a single one of them is a Steppe man.

12.Bachelor: So what am I supposed to do?

12.Bachelor: So what am I supposed to do?

13.Stanislav Rubin: Do pay a visit to governor Saburov. I wouldn't go to Vlad if I were you, he's too resourceful, and too inclined to drag you into his schemes... The Kains are also out of the question as anything that leads Georgiy to me would likely result in Simon's body being removed. And I still have a lot of work to do.

13.Stanislav Rubin: Do pay a visit to governor Saburov. I wouldn't go to Vlad if I were you, he's too resourceful, and too inclined to drag you into his schemes... The Kains are also out of the question as anything that leads Georgiy to me would likely result in Simon's body being removed. And I still have a lot of work to do.

14.Bachelor: Find someone else to obtain the samples! Our job is to study the specimen under the microscope, not to cut it out in some seedy alley!

14.Bachelor: Find someone else to obtain the samples! Our job is to study the specimen under the microscope, not to cut it out in some seedy alley!

15.Stanislav Rubin: Believe me, I tried my best. No one wants anything to do with the mutilation of dead bodies. Isidor's students have gone into hiding. I planned to approach the butchers, but Olgimsky has blocked off the Termitary. I would search for a stray butcher in town, there may be some, but I can't leave Simon's body. There is no one who would do it for us right now.

15.Stanislav Rubin: Believe me, I tried my best. No one wants anything to do with the mutilation of dead bodies. Isidor's students have gone into hiding. I planned to approach the butchers, but Olgimsky has blocked off the Termitary. I would search for a stray butcher in town, there may be some, but I can't leave Simon's body. There is no one who would do it for us right now.

16.Bachelor: I heard a rumour of a man who is well-equipped to both dissect the dead and gut the living. In fact, he's the son of the deceased healer, your Master. Did you get to meet him?

16.Bachelor: I heard a rumour of a man who is well-equipped to both dissect the dead and gut the living. In fact, he's the son of the deceased healer, your Master. Did you get to meet him?

17.Stanislav Rubin: I didn't. A few of my friends are trying to find him on my behalf, with no success yet.

17.Stanislav Rubin: I didn't. A few of my friends are trying to find him on my behalf, with no success yet.

18.Bachelor: That's unfortunate. I will try to think of some other option. See you soon, colleague.

18.Bachelor: That's unfortunate. I will try to think of some other option. See you soon, colleague.

18.Bachelor: I'm sure that whenever they find him, he will prove to be very helpful indeed. This is, after all, his line of occupation. He's bound to do a better job than I ever could. As for me, I've had enough of that already.

18.Bachelor: I'm sure that whenever they find him, he will prove to be very helpful indeed. This is, after all, his line of occupation. He's bound to do a better job than I ever could. As for me, I've had enough of that already.

16.Bachelor: Very well. I got agitated beyond reason. I'll bring you the sample.

16.Bachelor: Very well. I got agitated beyond reason. I'll bring you the sample.

14.Bachelor: Sounds reasonable. I'll see you soon.

14.Bachelor: Sounds reasonable. I'll see you soon.

10.Bachelor: What are the menkhu?

10.Bachelor: What are the menkhu?

11.Stanislav Rubin: Translated loosely as 'men who set apart the parts of a whole', the menkhu are the adepts of the Kin. Butchers, surgeons, prophets-any occupation that has to do with knowing the separate parts that comprise a whole...

11.Stanislav Rubin: Translated loosely as 'men who set apart the parts of a whole', the menkhu are the adepts of the Kin. Butchers, surgeons, prophets-any occupation that has to do with knowing the separate parts that comprise a whole...

12.Bachelor: Fine, but I am definitely not a menkhu. So what am I supposed to do?

12.Bachelor: Fine, but I am definitely not a menkhu. So what am I supposed to do?

13.Stanislav Rubin: Do pay a visit to governor Saburov. I wouldn't go to Vlad if I were you, he's too resourceful, and too inclined to drag you into his schemes... The Kains are also out of the question as anything that leads Georgiy to me would likely result in Simon's body being removed. And I still have a lot of work to do.

13.Stanislav Rubin: Do pay a visit to governor Saburov. I wouldn't go to Vlad if I were you, he's too resourceful, and too inclined to drag you into his schemes... The Kains are also out of the question as anything that leads Georgiy to me would likely result in Simon's body being removed. And I still have a lot of work to do.

14.Bachelor: Find someone else to obtain the samples! Our job is to study the specimen under the microscope, not to cut it out in some seedy alley!

15.Stanislav Rubin: Believe me, I tried my best. No one wants anything to do with the mutilation of dead bodies. Isidor's students have gone into hiding. I planned to approach the butchers, but Olgimsky has blocked off the Termitary. I would search for a stray butcher in town, there may be some, but I can't leave Simon's body. There is no one who would do it for us right now.

14.Bachelor: Sounds reasonable. I'll see you soon.

14.Bachelor: Sounds reasonable. I'll see you soon.

8.Bachelor: What about you? Do you possess this kind of privilege?

8.Bachelor: What about you? Do you possess this kind of privilege?

9.Stanislav Rubin: Hard to say... my Master was planning to 'bind me with the blood of his kin'. In other words, I was to become his foster son. He never got to complete the procedure. As a result, I am formally allowed to perform dissections-but few people know about it. Most of them still see me as a soldier, rather than a butcher.

9.Stanislav Rubin: Hard to say... my Master was planning to 'bind me with the blood of his kin'. In other words, I was to become his foster son. He never got to complete the procedure. As a result, I am formally allowed to perform dissections-but few people know about it. Most of them still see me as a soldier, rather than a butcher.

10.Bachelor: So you did military service?

10.Bachelor: So you did military service?

11.Stanislav Rubin: Not for long. I served in General Shoin's army until I was injured in the head by the Skerries. I was released soon thereafter.

11.Stanislav Rubin: Not for long. I served in General Shoin's army until I was injured in the head by the Skerries. I was released soon thereafter.

12.Bachelor: I hear you... But from what I can see, not everyone in the town belongs to the indigenous population?

6.Bachelor: What do you want to ask of me?

6.Bachelor: What do you want to ask of me?

7.Stanislav Rubin: I was going to ask you to bring a sample or two from one of the infected quarters. Be doubly careful though, and make sure to get the dissection fully cleared with one of the rulers, else the risk would be twice as high as needs be. I'd go myself, but there are reasons that make it impossible for me to leave Simon's body unattended.

8.Bachelor: That's some request... What is this additional danger you speak of?

8.Bachelor: That's some request... What is this additional danger you speak of?

9.Stanislav Rubin: Dissection of dead bodies is something that the locals strongly disapprove of. For Steppe people, the human body represents the world. Only a member of a special taglur-Burakh, to name one-is allowed to 'open it up'. This is a caste-based privilege, you see.

9.Stanislav Rubin: Dissection of dead bodies is something that the locals strongly disapprove of. For Steppe people, the human body represents the world. Only a member of a special taglur-Burakh, to name one-is allowed to 'open it up'. This is a caste-based privilege, you see.

10.Bachelor: Does everyone in the town share this same prejudice?

10.Bachelor: Does everyone in the town share this same prejudice?

11.Stanislav Rubin: No, of course not. But even those who are oblivious of the sacred meaning of the Kin's rituals would still oppose unsanctioned dissection, because it's traditionally inappropriate. A cultural taboo, if you will. An autopsy performed by anyone other than a true born menkhu is seen as blasphemy of the worst kind. Even incest is not as repulsive to them.

11.Stanislav Rubin: No, of course not. But even those who are oblivious of the sacred meaning of the Kin's rituals would still oppose unsanctioned dissection, because it's traditionally inappropriate. A cultural taboo, if you will. An autopsy performed by anyone other than a true born menkhu is seen as blasphemy of the worst kind. Even incest is not as repulsive to them.

13.Stanislav Rubin: These people are outlaws, and not a single one of them is a Steppe man.

14.Bachelor: So what am I supposed to do?

15.Stanislav Rubin: Do pay a visit to governor Saburov. I wouldn't go to Vlad if I were you, he's too resourceful, and too inclined to drag you into his schemes... The Kains are also out of the question as anything that leads Georgiy to me would likely result in Simon's body being removed. And I still have a lot of work to do.

17.Stanislav Rubin: Believe me, I tried my best. No one wants anything to do with the mutilation of dead bodies. Isidor's students have gone into hiding. I planned to approach the butchers, but Olgimsky has blocked off the Termitary. I would search for a stray butcher in town, there may be some, but I can't leave Simon's body. There is no one who would do it for us right now.

12.Bachelor: What are the menkhu?

12.Bachelor: What are the menkhu?

13.Stanislav Rubin: Translated loosely as 'men who set apart the parts of a whole', the menkhu are the adepts of the Kin. Butchers, surgeons, prophets-any occupation that has to do with knowing the separate parts that comprise a whole...

11.Stanislav Rubin: Hard to say... my Master was planning to 'bind me with the blood of his kin'. In other words, I was to become his foster son. He never got to complete the procedure. As a result, I am formally allowed to perform dissections-but few people know about it. Most of them still see me as a soldier, rather than a butcher.

9.Stanislav Rubin: Dissection of dead bodies is something that the locals strongly disapprove of. For Steppe people, the human body represents the world. Only a member of a special taglur-Burakh, to name one-is allowed to 'open it up'. This is a caste-based privilege, you see.

9.Stanislav Rubin: Dissection of dead bodies is something that the locals strongly disapprove of. For Steppe people, the human body represents the world. Only a member of a special taglur-Burakh, to name one-is allowed to 'open it up'. This is a caste-based privilege, you see.

10.Bachelor: Does everyone in the town share this same prejudice?

10.Bachelor: Does everyone in the town share this same prejudice?

11.Stanislav Rubin: No, of course not. But even those who are oblivious of the sacred meaning of the Kin's rituals would still oppose unsanctioned dissection, because it's traditionally inappropriate. A cultural taboo, if you will. An autopsy performed by anyone other than a true born menkhu is seen as blasphemy of the worst kind. Even incest is not as repulsive to them.

This is a one-of-a-kind opportunity for us to get what we need.

26.Bachelor: What am I supposed to do if Burakh refuses to help?

They are barely daunted with things that would scare us to death. The blood of a Steppe person belongs to the earth. One way or another, Burakh will be working in the infected quarters today.
